steps.title: Go get your blood tested to see what you may need to treat.
steps.content: Go get your blood tested to see what you may need to treat. According to the proponents of overmethylation, you will have high levels of copper in your blood, low levels of zinc, high levels of estrogen, or a high homocysteine levels if you’re overmethylated. The treatment for these deficiencies is going to be unique depending on which hormones or nutrients are high/low, so get a blood test and talk to your doctor to see what you can do to fix this problem if there is one. [1] X Trustworthy Source Harvard Medical School Harvard Medical School's Educational Site for the Public Go to source Some people suggest that folate, zinc, vitamin C or vitamin B supplements will help with overmethylation, but there’s no way to know which one you’ll need to take without the blood test. On top of that, there may be some underlying condition causing your deficiency if you have one, so don’t do anything here without seeing a doctor first! [2] X Trustworthy Source Harvard Medical School Harvard Medical School's Educational Site for the Public Go to source

steps.title: You may not have an issue with methylation.
steps.content: You may not have an issue with methylation. Your body definitely goes through methylation, but as a medical diagnosis there isn’t much evidence that you’ll need to treat or change your methylation. [3] X Research source Scientists working in the field of epigenetics are interested in methylation for gene therapy and mutation research purposes. [4] X Research source But methylation just describes the process of methyl groups being added to or removed from DNA; it may not be a recognized condition you can treat. [5] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source Your body goes through methylation millions of times a day. It’s possible for a gene to be overmethylated one minute, and undermethylated the other. [6] X Trustworthy Source Centers for Disease Control and Prevention Main public health institute for the US, run by the Dept. of Health and Human Services Go to source DNA methylation has definitely been implicated in certain mood disorders and conditions, but it’s probably not a causal relationship. In other words, while people with depression often have low levels of methylation, it’s not clear if those methylation levels are causing the depression or the other way around. [7] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source

steps.title: There are hundreds of symptoms according to some holistic healers.
steps.content: There are hundreds of symptoms according to some holistic healers. Due to the fact that methylation occurs everywhere in your body thousands of times a day, people have pinned a wide array of symptoms on overmethylation. While some are likely unrelated to methylation, potential symptoms include: [8] X Research source Depression, anxiety, self-harm, low motivation, and low sex drive. Trouble sleeping, tinnitus, dry eyes or mouth, nervous legs, and hyperactivity. Adverse reactions to SSRIs, SAMe, estrogen, or antihistamines. An absence of seasonal allergies, intense belief in religion, musical ability, or a tendency to be overweight.

steps.title: Live a healthy lifestyle to maintain standard methylation levels.
steps.content: Live a healthy lifestyle to maintain standard methylation levels. The things you do can influence your genes. If you smoke, eat a poor diet, don’t sleep, or expose yourself to excess stress, it may change the way your body processes nutrients. Living a healthy lifestyle may help your body process information from your DNA more efficiently! [9] X Research source Getting sick can change your methylation levels as well, and staying healthy will definitely decrease the odds you get sick! [10] X Trustworthy Source Centers for Disease Control and Prevention Main public health institute for the US, run by the Dept. of Health and Human Services Go to source

steps.title: Work with your doctor to develop a treatment plan.
steps.content: Work with your doctor to develop a treatment plan. Many of the symptoms of overmethylation can be tied to another diagnosis. See your doctor and talk to them about what you’re experiencing. Once they’ve identified the root cause of your symptoms, work with them to come up with a treatment plan that makes sense for you. [11] X Trustworthy Source National Institutes of Health U.S. government agency for biomedical and public health research Go to source If you are concerned with overmethylation, jot down any questions you have ahead of time and bring your list in with you to the doctor’s office. They’ll walk you through any concerns that you have. Overmethylation has been tied to everything from schizophrenia and cancer, to the common cold and seasonal allergies. [12] X Research source If you do have an underlying condition, focus your energy on treating it directly.

steps.title: Your methylation levels naturally change every day.
steps.content: Your methylation levels naturally change every day. Methylation is a genetic process, but it’s not the kind of genetic process that’s permanent or immutable. This is why scientists are so interested in studying methylation—so they can learn how to turn genes on or off! However, there are hundreds of things influencing this process in your body every day, and it’s extremely difficult to pinpoint any single behavior, process, or factor that causes changes to occur. [13] X Trustworthy Source Centers for Disease Control and Prevention Main public health institute for the US, run by the Dept. of Health and Human Services Go to source You have 20,000-25,000 genes, and methylation plays a role in all of them. [14] X Trustworthy Source MedlinePlus Collection of medical information sourced from the US National Library of Medicine Go to source On top of that, methylation levels change millions of time a day. Certain genes could be overmethylated at the same time that other genes are undermethylated!

steps.title: Your methylation levels naturally fluctuate more as you get older.
steps.content: Your methylation levels naturally fluctuate more as you get older. Your methylation levels are more likely to be stable and healthy the younger you are. [15] X Trustworthy Source Centers for Disease Control and Prevention Main public health institute for the US, run by the Dept. of Health and Human Services Go to source Over time, the possibility for mutations and abnormalities in your genetic processes goes up. [16] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source By doing your best to stay healthy, you may increase your odds that these changes occur over time. [17] X Research source

steps.title: See your doctor and get a blood test to see what’s going on.
steps.content: See your doctor and get a blood test to see what’s going on. There are certain blood test panels your doctor can order to take a look at certain methylation markers. [18] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source Since methylation influences how your body processes nutrients and hormones, a basic blood test should still tell you everything you’d need to know—even if it doesn’t tell you anything about your methylation levels. [19] X Research source

steps.title: You would need epigenetic profiling to get the full picture.
steps.content: You would need epigenetic profiling to get the full picture. To really get a look at your methylation levels in detail, you’d need to get your entire genome sequenced. [20] X Research source This isn’t necessarily something you’re likely to want to do, though. It’s extremely expensive, your insurance is unlikely to cover it, and you’re probably not going to get much of an insight from the results. [21] X Research source On top of this, your methylation levels change all the time depending on your behavior, age, and a variety of other factors.

steps.title: In theory, you can take SAMe supplements to boost methylation.
steps.content: In theory, you can take SAMe supplements to boost methylation. Ask your doctor if they think you’d benefit from taking S-adenosyl-L-methionine supplement. This compound is produced naturally, and it may help your body stabilize methylation levels. [22] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source However, there’s no conclusive evidence that SAMe supplements have a huge impact, and it may interact with other medications you take or negatively influence your health, so just talk to a doctor before you start taking it. [23] X Research source SAMe is a methyl donor, meaning that your body can use it to replace basically any missing nutrient for methylation processes. [24] X Trustworthy Source Oregon State University Linus Pauling Institute Research center dedicated to promoting optimal health through cutting-edge nutrition research and public outreach Go to source

steps.title: Eat a balanced diet to ensure that you get plenty of folates.
steps.content: Eat a balanced diet to ensure that you get plenty of folates. There’s some evidence that people who get a lot of folates from food have healthier levels of methylation. [25] X Research source Aim to consume 200 micrograms of folate a day. If you’re looking for some high-folate foods, try broccoli, brussels sprouts, vegetables, peas, liver, or breakfast cereal! [26] X Trustworthy Source National Health Service (UK) Public healthcare system of the UK Go to source Eat a healthy diet to ensure that you get enough folates. You won’t need to take a supplement so long as you eat a balance of lean proteins, vegetables, fruits, whole grains, and healthy fats. [27] X Trustworthy Source National Health Service (UK) Public healthcare system of the UK Go to source

steps.title: Changes in methylation levels may not necessarily be bad.
steps.content: Changes in methylation levels may not necessarily be bad. Changes to your methylation levels are not always a sign something is wrong. For example, a loss of methylation in a certain gene is associated with increased fetal growth and development. [28] X Trustworthy Source PLOS ONE Online peer-reviewed, open access scientific research journal Go to source Overmethylation of a different set of genes is associated with tumor suppression. [29] X Research source The point is, even if your methylation levels are off, it may not necessarily mean you’re unhealthy and it may just be your body’s natural response to a stimuli. [30] X Trustworthy Source Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences Official peer-reviewed and multidisciplary journal for the National Academy of Sciences. Go to source
